abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Phase of the
            Water Resources Planning and Management Project (WRPMP) for
            Africa were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was substantial, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Grantee performance was satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: lessons emerged from the WRPMP are
            related to: project rationale; Decision Support System (DSS)
            development; and sustainability. At project rational
            following lessons were learned: the project was conceived
            and designed on the assumption that countries need to have a
            commonly accepted knowledge base and analytical tools to
            enable improved understanding and informed discussions about
            water resources management and development opportunities,
            challenges, and trade-offs. This builds trust and
            confidence, breaks myths through sound analysis and
            information, and forms the technical knowledge platform for
            advancing cooperation. Capacity and knowledge is linked to a
            fourth risk, namely the ability to act in the best interest
            of the country without constraints, making decisions
            independently (sovereignty and autonomy). It is the
            application of the DSS over the next few years that are
            expected to reap the substantial benefits for cooperative
            management and development of the Nile basin. As a highly
            technical exercise by specialists, the development of a DSS
            runs the risk of being isolated and separated from its
            rationale. To avoid this, development of the DSS was a
            highly participatory process involving the riparian
            countries and in particular a key design feature of the
            project was to support capacity building for DSS use at a
            national level. This aimed to ensure understanding as well
            as relevance of the DSS to riparian issues. Public access to
            the tools and data is important to spread and maximize
            knowledge and understanding across the basin beyond the
            riparian governments. At DSS development lessons learned
            are: the business process for water resources decision
            making is at once an important starting condition but also a
            product of the project itself. Development of the DSS as a
            participatory process enabled technical interaction across
            all of the Nile basin countries for the first time.
            Developing data and information sharing protocols is
            critical and can be helped by global public data sets and
            development of the DSS itself. It thus requires adequate
            long term resources, appropriate team skills-mix, and
            attention to continuity of staff. Role of the basin
            professionals compared with international consultants should
            be carefully considered. Role of the basin professionals
            compared with international consultants should be carefully
            considered. A DSS should be inclusive of the range of
            development concerns and priorities, adopting a triple
            bottom line scope. The DSS should embed as early as possible
            in the long term institutional host. Lessons from
            sustainability include: the development of a DSS should be
            seen as part of a long term process and one part of the
            overall engagement with a basin. A DSS is a living asset
            that requires ongoing adaptation, refinement and software.
